statements.name: PROC TIMESERIES
statements.description: The TIMESERIES procedure analyzes time-stamped transactional data with respect to time and accumulates the data into a time series format. The procedure can perform trend and seasonal analysis on the transactions. After the transactional data are accumulated, time domain and frequency domain analysis can be performed on the accumulated time series. † Time series analyses performed by the TIMESERIES procedure include: o descriptive (global) statistics o seasonal decomposition/adjustment analysis o correlation analysis o cross-correlation analysis

arguments.name: CROSSPLOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the cross-variable graphical output desired. By default, the TIMESERIES procedure produces no graphical output.

arguments.name: SERIES
arguments.description: Plots the time series (OUT= data set).

arguments.name: CCF
arguments.description: Plots the cross-correlation functions (OUTCROSSCORR= data set).

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Same as PLOTS=(SERIES CCF).

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the input data for the procedure to create the time series. If the DATA= option is not specified, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

arguments.name: MAXERROR=
arguments.description: Limits the number of warning and error messages that are produced during the execution of the procedure to the specified value. The default is MAXERRORS=50. This option is particularly useful in BY-group processing where it can be used to suppress the recurring messages.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the time series variables specified in the subsequent VAR and CROSSVAR statements. If BY variables are specified, they are also included in the OUT= data set. If an ID variable is specified, it is also included in the OUT= data set. The values are accumulated based on the ID statement INTERVAL= or the ACCUMULATE= option or both. The OUT= data set is particularly useful when you want to further analyze, model, or forecast the resulting time series with other SAS/ETS procedures.

arguments.name: OUTCORR=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the univariate time domain statistics.

arguments.name: OUTCROSSCORR=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the cross-correlation statistics.

arguments.name: OUTDECOMP=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the decomposed and/or seasonally adjusted time series.

arguments.name: OUTSEASON=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the seasonal statistics. The statistics are computed for each season as specified by the ID statement INTERVAL= option or the PROC TIMESERIES statement SEASONALITY= option. The OUTSEASON= data set is particularly useful when analyzing transactional data for seasonal variations.

arguments.name: OUTSUM=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the descriptive statistics. The descriptive statistics are based on the accumulated time series when the ACCUMULATE= and/or SETMISSING= options are specified in the ID or VAR statements. The OUTSUM= data set is particularly useful when analyzing large numbers of series and a summary of the results are needed.

arguments.name: OUTTREND=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the trend statistics. The statistics are computed for each time period as specified by the ID statement INTERVAL= option. The OUTTREND= data set is particularly useful when analyzing transactional data for trends.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the univariate graphical output desired. By default, the TIMESERIES procedure produces no graphical output.
arguments.help: PLOTS=SERIES | RESIDUAL | CYCLES | CORR | ACF | PACF | IACF | WN | DECOMP | TCS | TCC | SIC | SC | SA | PCSA | IC | TC | CC | ALL

arguments.name: SERIES
arguments.description: Plots the time series (OUT= data set).

arguments.name: RESIDUAL
arguments.description: Plots the residual time series (OUT= data set).

arguments.name: CYCLES
arguments.description: Plots the seasonal cycles (OUT= data set).

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Plots the correlation panel (OUTCORR= data set).

arguments.name: ACF
arguments.description: Plots the autocorrelation function (OUTCORR= data set).

arguments.name: PACF
arguments.description: Plots the partial autocorrelation function (OUTCORR= data set).

arguments.name: IACF
arguments.description: Plots the inverse autocorrelation function (OUTCORR= data set).

arguments.name: WN
arguments.description: Plots the white noise probabilities (OUTCORR= data set).

arguments.name: DECOMP
arguments.description: Plots the seasonal adjustment panel (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: TCS
arguments.description: Plots the trend-cycle-seasonal component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: TCC
arguments.description: Plots the trend-cycle component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: SIC
arguments.description: Plots the seasonal-irregular component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: SC
arguments.description: Plots the seasonal component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: SA
arguments.description: Plots the seasonal adjusted component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: PCSA
arguments.description: Plots the percent change in the seasonal adjusted component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: IC
arguments.description: Plots the irregular component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: TC
arguments.description: Plots the trend component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: CC
arguments.description: Plots the cycle component (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Same as PLOTS=(SERIES ACF PACF IACF WN).

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Specifies the printed output desired. By default, the TIMESERIES procedure produces no printed output.

arguments.name: DECOMP
arguments.description: Prints the seasonal decomposition/adjustment table (OUTDECOMP= data set).

arguments.name: SEASONS
arguments.description: Prints the seasonal statistics table (OUTSEASON= data set).

arguments.name: DESCSTATS
arguments.description: Prints the descriptive statistics for the accumulated time series (OUTSUM= data set).

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Prints the descriptive statistics table for all time series (OUTSUM= data set).

arguments.name: TRENDS
arguments.description: Prints the trend statistics table (OUTTREND= data set).

arguments.name: PRINTDETAILS
arguments.description: Specifies that output requested with the PRINT= option be printed in greater detail.

arguments.name: SEASONALITY=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of the seasonal cycle. For example, SEASONALITY=3 means that every group of three time periods forms a seasonal cycle. By default, the length of the seasonal cycle is one (no seasonality) or the length implied by the INTERVAL= option specified in the ID statement. For example, INTERVAL=MONTH implies that the length of the seasonal cycle is 12.

arguments.name: SORTNAMES
arguments.description: Specifies that the variables specified in the VAR and CROSSVAR statements be processed in sorted order by the variable names. This option allows the output data sets to be presorted by the variable names.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Creates a separate table on a separate page for each BY group.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: CORR
statements.description: A CORR statement can be used with the TIMESERIES procedure to specify options related to time domain analysis of the accumulated time series. Only one CORR statement is allowed.

arguments.name: ACF
arguments.description: Autocorrelations

arguments.name: ACF2STD
arguments.description: Two standard errors beyond autocorrelations

arguments.name: ACFLPROB
arguments.description: Autocorrelation log probabilities

arguments.name: ACFNORM
arguments.description: Normalized autocorrelations

arguments.name: ACFPROB
arguments.description: Autocorrelation probabilities

arguments.name: ACFSTD
arguments.description: Autocorrelation standard errors

arguments.name: ACOV=
arguments.description: Autocovariances

arguments.name: IACF
arguments.description: Inverse autocorrelations

arguments.name: IACF2STD
arguments.description: Two standard errors beyond inverse autocorrelations

arguments.name: IACFLPROB
arguments.description: Inverse autocorrelation probabilities

arguments.name: IACFNORM
arguments.description: Normalized inverse autocorrelations

arguments.name: IACFSTD
arguments.description: Inverse autocorrelation standard errors

arguments.name: LAG
arguments.description: Time lag

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of variance products

arguments.name: PACF
arguments.description: Partial autocorrelations

arguments.name: PACF2STD
arguments.description: Two standard errors beyond partial autocorrelations

arguments.name: PACFLPROB
arguments.description: Partial autocorrelation log probabilities

arguments.name: PACFNORM
arguments.description: Partial normalized autocorrelations

arguments.name: PACFPROB
arguments.description: Partial autocorrelation probabilities

arguments.name: PACFSTD
arguments.description: Partial autocorrelation standard errors

arguments.name: WN
arguments.description: White noise test statistics

arguments.name: WNLPROB
arguments.description: White noise test log probabilities

arguments.name: WNPROB
arguments.description: White noise test probabilities

arguments.name: LAGS=
arguments.description: Specifies the list of lags to be stored in OUTCORR= data set or to be plotted. The list of lags must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, LAGS=(1,3) specifies the first then third lag.

arguments.name: NLAG=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lags to be stored in the OUTCORR= data set or to be plotted. The default is 24 or three times the length of the seasonal cycle, whichever is smaller. The LAGS= option takes precedence over the NLAG= option.

arguments.name: NPARMS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of parameters used in the model that created the residual time series. The number of parameters determines the degrees of freedom associated with the Ljung-Box statistics. The default is NPARMS=0. This option is useful when analyzing the residuals of a time series model with the number of parameters specified by NPARMS=number option.

arguments.name: TRANSPOSE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the OUTCORR= data set is recorded with the lags as the column names, or with the correlation statistics as the column names.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTCORR= data set is recorded with the correlation statistics as the column names. This is the default.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTCORR= data set is recorded with the lags as the column names instead of with the correlation statistics as the column names.

statements.name: CROSSCORR
statements.description: A CROSSCORR statement can be used with the TIMESERIES procedure to specify options that are related to cross-correlation analysis of the accumulated time series. Only one CROSSCORR statement is allowed.

arguments.name: CCF
arguments.description: Cross correlations

arguments.name: CCF2STD
arguments.description: Two standard errors beyond cross-correlations

arguments.name: CCFLPROB
arguments.description: Cross-correlation log probabilities

arguments.name: CCFNORM
arguments.description: Normalized cross-correlations

arguments.name: CCFPROB
arguments.description: Corss-correlation probabilities

arguments.name: CCFSTD
arguments.description: Cross-correlation standard errors

arguments.name: CCOV
arguments.description: Cross covariances

arguments.name: LAG
arguments.description: Time lag

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of variance products

arguments.name: LAGS=
arguments.description: Specifies the list of lags to be stored in OUTCROSSCORR= data set or to be plotted. The list of lags must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, LAGS=(1,3) specifies the first then third lag.

arguments.name: NLAG=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lags to be stored in the OUTCROSSCORR= data set or to be plotted. The default is 24 or three times the length of the seasonal cycle, whichever is smaller. The LAGS= option takes precedence over the NLAG= option.

arguments.name: TRANSPOSE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the OUTCROSSCORR= data set is recorded with the lags as the column names, or with the cross-correlation statistics as the column names.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTCROSSCORR= data set is recorded with the cross-correlation statistics as the column names. This is the default.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTCROSSCORR= data set is recorded with the lags as the column names instead of with the cross-correlation statistics as the column names.

statements.name: CROSSVAR
statements.description: The CROSSVAR statement lists the numeric variables in the DATA= data set whose values are to be accumulated to form the time series.

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period. The frequency (width of each time interval) is specified by the INTERVAL= option.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.

arguments.name: TOTAL
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: DIF=
arguments.description: Specifies the differencing to be applied to the accumulated time series. The list of differencing orders must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, DIF=(1,3) specifies first then third order differencing. Differencing is applied after time series transformation. The TRANSFORM= option is applied before the DIF= option.

arguments.name: SDIF=
arguments.description: Specifies the seasonal differencing to be applied to the accumulated time series. The list of seasonal differencing orders must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, SDIF=(1,3) specifies first then third order seasonal differencing. Differencing is applied after time series transformation. The TRANSFORM= option is applied before the SDIF= option.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are to be interpreted in the accumulated time series for variables listed in the VAR or CROSSVAR statement.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: NEXT
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: TRANSFORM=
arguments.description: Specifies the time series transformation to be applied to the accumulated time series.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No transformation. This is the default.

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Logarithmic transformation

arguments.name: SQRT
arguments.description: Square-root transformation

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: Logistic transformation

arguments.name: BOXCOX
arguments.description: Box-Cox transformation with parameter number where number is between –5 and 5.

statements.name: DECOMP
statements.description: A DECOMP statement can be used with the TIMESERIES procedure to specify options related to classical seasonal decomposition of the time series data. Only one DECOMP statement is allowed. The options specified affect all variables listed in the VAR statements. Decomposition can be performed only when the length of the seasonal cycle specified by the PROC TIMESERIES statement SEASONALITY= option or implied by the ID statement INTERVAL= option is greater than one.

arguments.name: CC
arguments.description: Trend component

arguments.name: IC
arguments.description: Irregular component

arguments.name: ORIG
arguments.description: Original series

arguments.name: PCSA
arguments.description: Percent change seasonally adjusted series

arguments.name: SA
arguments.description: Seasonally adjusted series

arguments.name: SC
arguments.description: Seasonal component

arguments.name: SCSTD
arguments.description: Seasonal component standard errors

arguments.name: SIC
arguments.description: Seasonal-irregular component

arguments.name: TC
arguments.description: Trend component

arguments.name: TCC
arguments.description: Trend-cycle component

arguments.name: TCS
arguments.description: Trend-cycle-seasonal component

arguments.name: LAMBDA=
arguments.description: Specifies the Hodrick-Prescott filter parameter for trend-cycle decomposition. The default is λ=1600. Filtering applies when the trend component or the cycle component is requested. If filtering is not specified, this option is ignored.

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of decomposition to be used to decompose the time series.

arguments.name: ADD
arguments.description: Additive decomposition

arguments.name: MULT
arguments.description: Multiplicative decomposition

arguments.name: LOGADD
arguments.description: Log-additive decomposition

arguments.name: PSEUDOADD
arguments.description: Pseudo-additive decomposition

arguments.name: MULTORADD
arguments.description: Multiplicative or additive decomposition, depending on data

arguments.name: NPERIODS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of time periods to be stored in the OUTDECOMP= data set when the TRANSPOSE=YES option is specified. If the TRANSPOSE=NO option is specified, the NPERIODS= option is ignored. If the NPERIODS= option is positive, the first or beginning time periods are recorded. If the NPERIODS= option is negative, the last or ending time periods are recorded.

arguments.name: TRANSPOSE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the OUTDECOMP= data set be recorded with the the statistics as the column names, or with the time periods as the column names.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTDECOMP= data set be recorded with the the statistics as the column names.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTDECOMP= data set be recorded with the time periods as the column names instead of with the statistics as the column names.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement names a numeric variable that identifies observations in the input and output data sets. The ID variable’s values are assumed to be SAS date, time, or datetime values. In addition, the ID statement specifies the (desired) frequency associated with the time series. The ID statement options also specify how the observations are accumulated and how the time ID values are aligned to form the time series. The information specified affects all variables listed in subsequent VAR statements. If the ID statement is specified, the INTERVAL= option must also be used. If an ID statement is not specified, the observation number, with respect to the BY group, is used as the time ID.
statements.help: ID <ACCUMULATE=<NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE>... ><ALIGN=<BEGINNING | MIDDLE | ENDING>><END=date | datetime> ...

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period. The frequency (width of each time interval) is specified by the INTERVAL= option.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM|MIN | MEDIAN|MED | MAXIMUM|MAX | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV|STD | CSS | USS

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.

arguments.name: TOTAL
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: Controls the alignment of SAS dates used to identify output observations.

arguments.name: BEGINNING
arguments.description: SAS dates aligned in the BEGINNING.

arguments.name: MIDDLE
arguments.description: SAS dates aligned in the MIDDLE.

arguments.name: ENDING
arguments.description: SAS dates aligned in the ENDING.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date or datetime literal value that represents the end of the data.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS format for the time ID values. If the FORMAT= option is not specified, the default format is implied from the INTERVAL= option.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the frequency of the accumulated time series.
arguments.help: INTERVAL=DAY | HOUR | MINUTE | SECOND | WEEK | MONTH | YEAR | QTR | TENDAY | SEMIMONTH | SEMIYEAR

arguments.name: DAY
arguments.description: DAY interval

arguments.name: HOUR
arguments.description: HOUR interval

arguments.name: MINUTE
arguments.description: MINUTE interval

arguments.name: SECOND
arguments.description: SECOND interval

arguments.name: WEEK
arguments.description: WEEK interval

arguments.name: MONTH
arguments.description: MONTH interval

arguments.name: YEAR
arguments.description: YEAR interval

arguments.name: QTR
arguments.description: QTR interval

arguments.name: TENDAY
arguments.description: TENDAY interval

arguments.name: SEMIMONTH
arguments.description: SEMIMONTH interval

arguments.name: SEMIYEAR
arguments.description: SEMIYEAR interval

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that the time ID values are not in sorted order. The ESM procedure sorts the data with respect to the time ID prior to analysis.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either input or accumulated) are assigned in the accumulated time series. If a number n is specified (SETMISSING=n), missing values are set to that number.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: NEXT
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date or datetime literal value that represents the beginning of the data.

statements.name: SEASON
statements.description: A SEASON statement can be used with the TIMESERIES procedure to specify options that are related to seasonal analysis of the time-stamped transactional data. Only one SEASON statement is allowed. The options specified affect all variables specified in the VAR statements. Seasonal analysis can be performed only when the length of the seasonal cycle specified by the PROC TIMESERIES statement SEASONALITY= option or implied by the ID statement INTERVAL= option is greater than one.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Corrected sum of squares

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Maximum value

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Mean value

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Median value

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Minimum value

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of nonmissing observations

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Number of missing observations

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: RANGE
arguments.description: Range value

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Standard deviation

arguments.name: SUM
arguments.description: Summation value

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Uncorrected sum of squares

arguments.name: TRANSPOSE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the OUTSEASON= data set be recorded with the the statistics as the column names, or with the seasonal indices as the column names.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTSEASON= data set be recorded with the the statistics as the column names.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTSEASON= data set be recorded with the seasonal indices as the column names instead of the statistics as the column names.

statements.name: SPECTRA
statements.description: A SPECTRA statement can be used with the TIMESERIES procedure to specify which statistics appear in the OUTSPECTRA= data set. The SPECTRA statement options are used in performing a spectral analysis on the variables listed in the VAR statement. These options affect values that are produced in the PROC TIMESERIES statement’s OUTSPECTRA= data set, and in the periodogram and spectral density estimate. Only one SPECTRA statement is allowed.

arguments.name: COS
arguments.description: Cosine transform

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Frequency in radians from 0 to π.

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: Periodogram

arguments.name: PERIOD
arguments.description: Period or wavelength

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: Spectral density estimates

arguments.name: SIN
arguments.description: Sine transform

arguments.name: ADJMEAN
arguments.description: Subtracts the series mean before performing the Fourier decomposition. This sets the first periodogram ordinate to 0 rather than to 2n times the squared mean. This option is commonly used when the periodograms are to be plotted to prevent a large first periodogram ordinate from distorting the scale of the plot.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of a window drawn around the spectral density estimate in a spectral density versus frequency plot. Based on approximations proposed by Brockwell and Davis (1991), periodogram ordinates fall within this window with a confidence level of 1-ALPHA. The value ALPHA must be between 0 and 1; the default is 0.5.

arguments.name: BARTLETT
arguments.description: Specifies the BARTLETT kernel smoothing function to calculate a spectral density estimate as the moving average of periodogram ordinates. The DOMAIN= option specifies how the smoothing function is interpreted. The available domain values are: FREQUENCY smooths the periodogram ordinates.

arguments.name: PARZEN
arguments.description: Specifies the PARZEN kernel smoothing function for calculating a spectral density estimate as the moving average of periodogram ordinates. The DOMAIN= option specifies how the smoothing function is interpreted. The available domain values are: FREQUENCY smooths the periodogram ordinates.

arguments.name: QS
arguments.description: Specifies the quadratic spectral (QS) kernel smoothing function for calculating a spectral density estimate as the moving average of periodogram ordinates. The DOMAIN= option specifies how the smoothing function is interpreted. The available domain values are: FREQUENCY smooths the periodogram ordinates.

arguments.name: TRUNCAT
arguments.description: Specifies the TRUNCATed kernel smoothing function for calculating a spectral density estimate as the moving average of periodogram ordinates. The DOMAIN= option specifies how the smoothing function is interpreted. The available domain values are: FREQUENCY smooths the periodogram ordinates.

arguments.name: TUKEY
arguments.description: Specifies the TUKEY-Hanning kernel smoothing function for calculating a spectral density estimate as the moving average of periodogram ordinates. The DOMAIN= option specifies how the smoothing function is interpreted. The available domain values are: FREQUENCY smooths the periodogram ordinates.

arguments.name: WEIGHTS
arguments.description: Specifies the relative weights used in computing a spectral density estimate as the moving average smoothing of periodogram ordinates. If neither a WEIGHTS option nor a kernel function is specified, the spectral density estimate is identical to the unmodified periodogram. The following SPECTRA statement uses the WEIGHTS option to specify equal weighting for each of the three adjacent periodogram ordinates centered on each spectral density estimate:

statements.name: SSA
statements.description: An SSA statement can be used with the TIMESERIES procedure to specify options that are related to singular spectrum analysis (SSA) of the accumulated time series. Only one SSA statement is allowed.

arguments.name: GROUPS=
arguments.description: Specifies the lists that categorize window lags into groups. The window lags must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, GROUPS=(1,3) (2,4) specifies that the first and third window lags form the first group and the second and fourth window lags form the second group. If no GROUPS= option is specified, the window lags are divided into two groups based on the THRESHOLDPCT= value.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the window length to be used in the analysis. It represents the maximum lag used in the SSA autocovariance calculations. The number specified by the LENGTH= option must be greater than one and less than 1000. When the SEASONALITY= option is provided or inferred by the INTERVAL= option in the ID statement the default window length is the smaller of two times the length of the seasonal cycle and one half the length of the time series. When no seasonality value is available the default window length is the smaller of 12 and one half the length of the time series.

arguments.name: NPERIODS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of time periods to be stored in the OUTSSA= data set when the TRANSPOSE=YES option is specified. If the TRANSPOSE option is not specified, the NPERIODS= option is ignored. The NPERIODS= option specifies the number of OUTSSA= data set variables to contain the groups.

arguments.name: THRESHOLDPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies a percentage used to divide the SSA components into two groups based on the cumulative percentage of their singular values. The percentage specified by the THRESHOLDPCT= option must be greater than zero and less than 100. The default is THRESHOLDPCT=90.

arguments.name: TRANSPOSE=
arguments.description: Specifies which values are recorded as column names in the OUTSSA= data set.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the specified groups be recorded as the column names.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the time periods be recorded as the column names instead of the specified groups as the column names.

statements.name: TREND
statements.description: A TREND statement can be used with the TIMESERIES procedure to specify options related to trend analysis of the time-stamped transactional data. Only one TREND statement is allowed. The options specified affect all variables specified in the VAR statements.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Corrected sum of squares

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Maximum value

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Mean value

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Median value

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Minimum value

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of nonmissing observations

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Number of missing observations

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: RANGE
arguments.description: Range value

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Standard deviation

arguments.name: SUM
arguments.description: Summation value

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Uncorrected sum of squares

arguments.name: NPERIODS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of time periods to be stored in the OUTTREND= data set when the TRANSPOSE=YES option is specified. If the TRANSPOSE option is not specified, the NPERIODS= option is ignored. The NPERIODS= option specifies the number of OUTTREND= data set variables to contain the trend statistics and is therefore limited to the maximum allowable number of SAS variables.

arguments.name: TRANSPOSE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the OUTTREND= data set be recorded with the the statistics as the column names, or with the time periods as the column names.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTTREND= data set be recorded with the the statistics as the column names.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the OUTTREND= data set be recorded with the time periods as the column names instead of with the statistics as the column names.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: The VAR statement lists the numeric variables in the DATA= data set whose values are to be accumulated to form the time series.

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period. The frequency (width of each time interval) is specified by the INTERVAL= option.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.

arguments.name: TOTAL
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: DIF=
arguments.description: Specifies the differencing to be applied to the accumulated time series. The list of differencing orders must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, DIF=(1,3) specifies first then third order differencing. Differencing is applied after time series transformation. The TRANSFORM= option is applied before the DIF= option.

arguments.name: SDIF=
arguments.description: Specifies the seasonal differencing to be applied to the accumulated time series. The list of seasonal differencing orders must be separated by spaces or commas. For example, SDIF=(1,3) specifies first then third order seasonal differencing. Differencing is applied after time series transformation. The TRANSFORM= option is applied before the SDIF= option.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are to be interpreted in the accumulated time series for variables listed in the VAR or CROSSVAR statement.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: NEXT
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: TRANSFORM=
arguments.description: Specifies the time series transformation to be applied to the accumulated time series.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No transformation. This is the default.

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Logarithmic transformation

arguments.name: SQRT
arguments.description: Square-root transformation

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: Logistic transformation

arguments.name: BOXCOX
arguments.description: Box-Cox transformation with parameter number where number is between –5 and 5.
